intro: Cirsium leucophanum, commonly known as the white hawksbeard, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of central and southern Europe. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and basal leaves that are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs. Its pale yellow to white flowers bloom in late summer, attracting various pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Cirsium leucophanum is often found in dry meadows, rocky slopes, and woodland edges, thriving in well-drained soils.
